Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: śormad-sa śorma-ńť;write-PRS/FUT.DEF.1SG>3SG letter-DEF.GEN.SG;I will write the letter;|śormad-siń śorma-ťńeń write-PRS/FUT.DEF.1SG>3PL letter-DEF.GEN.PL;I will write the letters;

Name: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: paro či-ťńe-ste;good day-DEF.ELA.PL;on the good days;
Comment: In attributive clauses the modifier has no case/number marker.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Source: Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kort-an marto-nzo;speak-PRS.1SG with-PX.3SG.GEN;I (will) speak with him/her;
Comment: Possessive suffixes can be added to a range of pospositions to show the person and number of an oblique argument.

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: pr'aka-n' pan'e-mste-nze čat'mon'-in';pie-INDF.GEN bake-GER-3SG>3SG be_silent-PST1.1SG;On her baking a pie I kept silence;

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ram-in' alaša;buy-PST.1SG horse;I bought a horse;|ram-ija alaš-an't'; buy-PST.1SG>3SG horse-DEF.GEN;I bought the horse;
Comment: Indefinite verb + indefinite nominative object expresses action that is not completed, whereas definite transitive verb + definite/possessive object expresses action that is completed.

Name: Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: lovno-sa kiniga-ńť;read-DEF.PRS.1SG>3SG book-DEF.GEN.SG;I will have read the book;|lovn-an kiniga-ńť; read-PRS.1SG book-DEF.GEN.SG;I am reading the book;
Comment: The definite predicate + the DEF/PX object expresses a completed action, whereas the indefinite predicate + the DEF/PX object expresses a progressive action; the INDF predicate + INDF object (e.g. lovn-an kin'iga) can imply both a fact and a process. Thus, the DEF/INDF object correlates with aspectuality.

Name: Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there differential subject marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: Pando pŕa-so kas-i čuvto;mountain.NOM head-INDF.INE.SG grow-PRS.3SG tree.INDF.NOM.SG;on the top of the mountain a tree grows;|Čuvto-ś kas-i pando pŕa-so;tree-DEF.NOM.SG grow-PRS.3SG pando-mountain.NOM pŕa-INDF.INE.SG;The tree grows on a mountain top;|Mo-ń uľiť umaŕ (<umar'-en') čuvto-n;I-GEN be-PRS.3PL apple.NOM(<GEN) tree-PX.1SG>3PL;I have apple trees;
Comment: The subject may be INDF/DEF or POSS (the pronominal subject is not obligatory).

Name: Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ćora-ś ńeji-źe ovto-ńt di tu-ś čije-ź;man-DEF.NOM.SG see-DEF.PST1.3SG>3SG bear-DEF.GEN(=ACC).SG and go-PST1.3SG run-GER;The man saw the bear and went (away) running;|ćora-ś ovto-ńť ńejemste-nze tu-ś čije-ź;man-DEF.NOM.SG bear-DEF.GEN(ACC).SG see-GER-3SG>3SG go-PST1.3SG run-GER;The man seeing the bear went away running;

Name: Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: jak-il'in', jakśi-ĺiń;go-PST2.1SG vs. go-PST2.1SG;I used to go;
Comment: PST2 expresses habituality; -s'- in jakśi-ĺiń is a frequentative suffix (lexical).

Name: Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: sa-kšn-oms;come-FRQ-INF;to come several times;
Comment: In addition, the frequentative meaning can be associated with the PST2 used to convey habituality (see UT016).

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: lovni-ľiń śńardo inže sa-ś;read-PST2.1SG when visitor.NOM come-PST1.3SG;I was reading when a visitor came;|uľń-iń orša-ź;be-PST1.1SG dress-PTCP2;I was (being) dressed; |orša-ź-eľiń; dress-PTCP2-PST2.1SG;I was (being) dressed /I used to be dressed;
Comment: PST2 can be used to express progressivity and repeated actions. The 'be' form in PST1 can also be used in the progressive meanig.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: moĺ-an kudo-v;go-PRS.1SG  home-INDF.LAT;I go/am going/will go home;
Comment: The forms of present cover both present and future time.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: PST1/PST2 express indefinite/progressive as well as completed actions (PST1) refferring to past (not sequence in time): mol'-in' 'I went, was walking': mol'i-l'-in' 'I was going, used to go'. They also differ by aspect.

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: jaki-ľiť ťeatra-v? -- eź-iľiń;go-PST2.2SG theatre-LAT -- NEG-PST2.1SG;Did you (usually) go to the theatre? --No, (I did not);
Comment: Past Indefinite has tense and person markers; it is followed by the connegative: ez'-in' jaka; in PST2, it has also aspect marker, l': ez'-il'-in' jaka. Negation expressed by aras' 'be missing', apak 'not (done)' (non-verbal predication) have these markers, too, e.g. araś-el´iń kudo-so (be_missing-PST2.1SG  home-INDF.INE) '(I) was not (staying) at home', apak-ol´ t´eje-ź (NEG-PST2.3SG do-PTCP2) '(it) was not done'.

Name: Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: araś-an/-el´iń;NEG-PRS.1SG/-PST2.1SG;I am/was missing;|eź-iń/-iľiń korta NEG-PST1.1SG/PST2.1SG speak.CNG;I did not speak/was not speaking;apak-at/-oĺiť orša-ź;NEG-PRS.2SG/-PST2.2SG dress-PTCP2;I am/was not dressed;

Name: Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: mor-ikseľ-iń moro;sing-DES-1SG song-ACC;I wanted (=was about) to sing a song;

Name: Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: Ul´e-vel´ ška-m, mol´e-vľiń/mol'in'-d'er'a-vl'in' t´eatra-v;be-CONJ.3SG time-PX.1SG>3SG go-CONJ./COND.CONJ.1SG theatre.INDF.LAT;If I had time I would go to/have visited  the theatre.

Name: Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: Mor-ińďeŕa-vľiť moro, mon maŕa-vľiťiń;sing-COND-CONJ.2SG song.INDF.ACC I.NOM hear-DEF.CONJ.1SG>2SG;If you had sung a song, I would have heard you;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: moro-t'n'e mora-ma-t/mora-ma-l't'; song-DEF.NOM.PL sing-DEB-PRS/PST2.3PL; the songs must/had to be sung;
Comment: The debitive forms can constitute a one-word sentence without the pronominal subject (the subject is not overt): Mora- ma 'it has to be sung'.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: sova-v-an;enter-PASS/REFL-PRS.1SG;I can enter;|mo-ńeń t´eve-ś t´eje-v-i;I-DAT work-DEF.NOM.SG do-PRS-PASS/REFL-3SG;I can do the work;
Comment: The marker passive/reflexive marker v is used to express capability, possibility, passive voice (depending on a context).

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ul´e-ze;be-OPT.3SG;let it be;|sova-zo;enter-OPT.3SG 'let him/her enter;
Comment: The optative marker is z.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ul´e-zan šumbra;be-OPT.1SG healthy;let me be healthy;

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Conjunctive is used to express wish/desire/will in simple clauses: soda-vl'-in' s'ed'e lamo 'I wish I knew more, I would like to know more'.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there reflexive conjugation?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: There is no reflexive conjugation, there is only the passive/reflexive marker v, e.g. maŕa-ń tomba-v-ś keď-eze (Mary-GEN hurt-REFL-PST1.3SG hand/arm-PX.3SG>3SG) 'Mary's hand/arm got hurt'.

Name: Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: However, with verbs like 'eat' and 'drink'  also ablative is used, e.g. mon andsa sonze sivel'd'e (1SG feed-1SG>3SG 3SG-GEN meat-ABL 'I feed him/her meat'). Other verbs rarely require ablative marking.

Name: Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: and-samiź;feed-DEF.PRS.2PL/3PL>1PL;you/they will give food to us;|andi-miź;feed-DEF.PST1.2PL/3PL>1PL;you/they gave food to me;
Comment: There is syncretism between the 2PL and 3PL forms of definite conjugation.

Name: Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ťejńe-siź iśťa;do-DEF.3PL>3SG this;They do it like this/It is done like this;|Kši-ńť pań-siź;bread-DEF.GEN.SG bake-PRS/FUT.DEF.3PL>3SG;The bread will be baked;

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ujiń-ďeŕ-at vasov - a veĺavtov-at;swim-COND.2SG far - NEG return-PRS.2SG;if you swim (=one swims) far - you (=s/he) won't (be able to) turn back;

Name: Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: t´eje-ma;do-DEB;(It) must be done;

Name: Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: Mol´-an Moskov-ov ramśeme;go-PRS.1SG Moscow-LAT do_shopping-INF2;I will go to Moscow to do shopping;

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: piź-i;rain-PRS.3SG;It's raining;

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The copula is covert, e.g. son erźa (s/he.NOM Erzya.PRS.3SG) 's/he is an Erzyan'.

Name: Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: Ton uĺ-at kudo-so?;you be-PRS.2SG home-INE;Will you  be at home?;
Comment: The overt present forms of the copula express  future; predicate nominals have the cliticized PRS and PST forms of uĺ-ems: kudo-s-an (home-INE-PRS.1SG) 'I am at home', kudo-so-ĺiń (home-INE-PST2.1SG) 'I was at home'.

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kudo-so;home-INDF.INE.PRS.3SG;S/he is at home;
Comment: Covert forms are used with 3SG. In other persons, the copula is overt, e.g. ušo-s-an < ušo-so-(ul´)an (outside-INE-PRS.1SG) 'I am outside'. The copula is also used in existential clauses, e.g. mon' uľ-i/-t' t'ev'em, -n' Gen + be-3SG/PL work-POSS.1SG>3SG/P 'I have work, -s'. toso ul'i ľej there be-PRS.3SG river.NOM) 'There is a river there'.

Name: Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Pet´a-t-Mar´a-t Petja-PL Mar´a-PL 'Pete and Mary'; Pet´a Mar´a marto Petja.NOM Mar´a.NOM with 'Pete with Mary'; Pet´a lovn-i di śormad-i (Pete.NOM read-PRS.3SG and = Russ. da  write-PRS.3SG 'Pete reads and writes'.

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: araś/-ť;NEG.PRS.3SG/PL;is/are missing;
Comment: Affirmative: ul'-i/-it' be-PRS.3SG/PL;ul'n-es'/-es't' be-PST1.3SG/PL mon' ul'n'-es' katka-m 'I had a cat'. Negative: aras'/aras't' PRS.3SG/PL, aras'-el'/-el't' PST2.3SG/PL, mon' aras'el' katka-m'I did not have a cat'.

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: In the present tense, negation is symmetric, e.g. kort-an : a kort-an (speak-PRS.1SG : NEG speak-PRS.1SG) 'I speak : I don't speak'.

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: a korti-ća;NEG speak-PTCP1;not speaking, taciturn;|a večkevi-ks;NEG like-PTCP1;not likeable;| a mol'e-ms;NEG go.INF;not to go;

Name: Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ťej-eź vs. apak t´eje tev;do-PTCP2 vs. NEG do.CNG work;done  vs. work that has not been done;|čij-eź vs. apak čije;run-GER vs. NEG run.CNG;running vs. not running;|šľa-ź-an vs. apak šľa-ź-an;NEG wash-PTCP2-PRS.1SG;I am not washed;
Comment: apak 'not' is used with PTCP2 and GER in asymmetric construction. In nonverbal forms, the construction is symmetric: orša-z'-an dress-PTCP.PRS.1SG 'I am dressed' apak orša-z'-an 'I am not dressed'. Independently used, apak can have tense-person markers: apak-an PRS.1SG, apak-ol't' PST2.3PL.

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: uči-ća lomań;wait-PTCP1 person.DEF.NOM/ACC.SG ;a waiting person;|učo-źeś/-eńť;wait-PTCP2 person.DEF.NOM/GEN.SG;the person whom (they) wait;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ťeje-ź ťev;do-PST.PTCP work.NOM.SG;a work that is done;|pra-ź lopa;fall-PST.PTCP leaf.NOM.SG;a fallen leaf;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Infinitives can be found in such a function.

Name: Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a future participle?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: moń večkev-iksem (večkev-iks) lomań-em;1SG.GEN love-PTCP1-PX.1SG>3SG (love-PTCP1) person-PX.1SG>3SG.NOM;my beloved (person);ńeje-ź-est;see-PTCP2-PX.3PL>3SG;what they saw;
Comment: This is possible with PTCP1 as well as PTCP2.

Name: Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: saje-ma ťejťeŕ;take-PTCP/DEB girl-INDF.NOM.SG;a girl to marry;|ťejťeŕ-eń saje-ma;girl-INDF.GEN taking-INDF.NOM.SG;marriage, the taking of a girl;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: mori-ća lomań/-eś;sing-PTCP1 person.NOM.INDF/-DEF;(a/the) singing person;|mori-ća/-ś;;a/the singer;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: modaś sokaź 'pelto on kynnetty', tuś avaŕďeź 'hän lähti itkien'

Name: Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: saj-ť umaŕ;take-IMP.2SG apple.INDF.ACC.SG;Take an apple;

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: Iľi-k jalga-t stuvto;NEG-IMP.2SG>3SG friend-PX.2SG>3SG forget.CNG;Do not forget your friend;

Name: Are there preverbs?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there verbal prefixes?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be marked like possessors?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ejďe-ńť šľamo-zo;child-DEF.GEN.SG washing-PX.3SG>3SG;the child's washing himself/herself / (his/her) washing the child;

Name: Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be marked like the direct object?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kofija-do śimema;coffee-INDF.ABL drinking;coffee drinking;|śim-an kofija-do;drink-1SG coffee-INDF.ABL;I drink coffee;

Name: Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ćora-ś seŕej;man-DEF.NOM.SG tall.PRS.3SG;the man is tall;| ćora-ťńe seŕej-ť;man-DEF.NOM.PL tall-PRS.3PL;the men are tall;

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: sonze kise  >  kise-nze;s/he-GEN for > for-PX.3SG;for him/her;|sinst ej-ste > ej-ste-st  they-GEN out_of > out_of-PX.3PL.ELA;out of them;

Name: Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: (ava-nzo) vakss : vaksso : ;mother-POSS.INE.3SG>3SG (to) near: near : (from) near;to near : by, near : from near (his/her mother);

Name: Is case compounding possible?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: piŕe-va-ťńe-ń-ste meźejak eź kado;(vegetable) garden-PROL-DEF.PL-INDF.GEN-INDF.ELA nothing NEG-PST1.3SG leave.CNG;of those (that were) in the gardens (it) left nothing;

Name: Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kavto ćora;two man.SG;two men;|kemeń panar;ten shirt.SG;ten shirts;
Comment: With numerals 2 through 10 the noun is used in singular, with other series of numerals singular or plural is used, e.g. śado lomań/-ť 'hundred persons'.

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: narmuń-eń pize;bird-INDF.GEN.SG nest.NOM;a bird's nest;|narmuńe-ńť pize-ze;bird-DEF.GEN.SG nest-PX.3SG>3SG.NOM;the bird's nest;|narmuńe-nze pize-ś;bird-PX.3SG>3SG.GEN nest-DEF.NOM.SG;his/her bird's nest;

Name: Is there a dative case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ćora-ńeń/-ńťeń;man-DAT.INDF.SG/-DEF.SG;to a/the man;|ćora-nsteń;son-PX.3SG>3SG.DAT;to his/her son;

Name: Is there a terminative case?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The terminative meaning is conveyed by the ILL.INDF (-s) and DAT.DEF (-ńťeń), e.g. pačkoďiń škola-s/-ńťeń (reach-PST1.1SG school-INDF.ILL.SG/DEF.DAT.SG) 'I reached a/the school'.

Name: Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: lovso-vtomo;milk-ABE;without milk;|kši-vťeme;bread-ABE;without bread;

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: uľća-va/-vańť/-vanok;street-INDF.PROL/DEF.PROL/PX.1PL>3SG ;along a/the/our street;
Comment: In addition to the prolative -va/-ga/-ka there is also the suffix -ja mainly used in adverbs, e.g. ťi-ja 'here, this way', śi-ja 'there, that way'.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: piŕe-s;garden-INDF.ILL;into a garden';

Name: Is there a locative case that marks location?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: mašina-so;car-INE;by car;
Comment: The inessive -so/-se is also used to mark an instrument.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks source?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: veď-ste;water-ELA;out of the water;
Comment: Locative is also used to mark time: ńiľe-ste 'at four o'clock'.

Name: Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there two sets of local cases?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a third set of local cases?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The inessive -so/-se also appears in the instrumental function, e.g. salmuks-so (needle-INS) 'by/with a needle'.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ejďe-ńek;child-COM;together/alongside with his/her child'.
Comment: However, -ńek does not have definite forms and possessive forms. Accompaniment can also be expressed by the postposition marto 'with', e.g. ejďe-nze marto (child-PX.3SG>3SG.GEN with) 'with his/her child'.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: tarka-ś ťejev-ś mazije-ks;place-DEF.NOM.SG become-PST1.3SG beautiful-INDF.NOM.TRA;The place became beautiful;|son-ze lov-iť pŕevej lomań-eks;s/he-DAT consider-PRS.3PL intelligent person.INDF.TRA.SG;S/he is considered an intelligent person;

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kemeń-ška;ten-COMP;nearly, about ten;|ťe-ń kuvalma-ška;this-GEN length-COMP.PRS.3SG;is of about this length;

Name: Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The dative is used (see UT082).

Name: Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: oš;city.INDF.NOM.SG;a city;| oš-oś;city-DEF.NOM.SG;the city;
Comment: There is the definite declension, which identifies the object in focus.

Name: Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Possession is usually marked by GEN, e.g. ćora-ń ľem male-INDF.GEN name.NOM 'a male name'. In some less prototypical cases of possession, also NOM can be found, e.g. čuvto/čuvto-ń lopa tree.INDF.NOM/-INDF.GEN leaf.NOM 'a leaf of a tree'.

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be marked with the nominative?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kudo-zo house-PX.3SG>3SG.NOM 'his/her house';kudo-nzo house-PX.3SG>3PL.NOM 'his/her house-s'
Comment: However, there are also syncretic forms: non-singular possession (multiple possessor-multiple possessed) overlaps with (multiple possessor - singular possessed): jalga-nok/-nk/-st friend-PX.1/2/3PL>3SG/3PL 'our friend/-s'; e.g. jalga-nok sa-ś friend-PX.1PL>3SG.NOM came-PST1.3SG 'our friend came', jalga-nok sa-śť friend-PX.1PL>3PL.NOM came-PST1.3PL 'our friends came.'

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ška-zo/-ś sa-ś;time-PX.3SG>3SG/-DEF.NOM.SG come-PST1.3SG;The time came;| či-ze/-ś ľiś-ś;sun-PX.3SG>3SG/-DEF.NOM.SG come_out-PST1.3SG;The sun came out;
Comment: 3SG possessive suffix -zo/-ze is parallel to the DEF marker -ś when used with some of the terms of natural phenomena.

Name: Is there animacy distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: meźe;;what;|kije;;who;

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The pronoun kije 'who' is not used, kona 'who, that, which' is used instead; it appears with animates: lomań-eś/buka-ś, kona sa-ś ťeze (person/ox-DEF.NOM.SG who/which/that come-PST1.3SG here) 'The person/ox who/which came here', as well as with inanimates: ťeľe-ś kona juta-ś  (winter-DEF.NOM.3SG which pass-PST1.3SG) 'the winter that is over'.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: See the comment in UT107.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ťe meźe-jak a sodi;this.DEF.NOM anything-ACC.SG NEG know-PRS.3SG;This (one) does not know anything;
Comment: The demonstrative pronouns ťe 'this', ńe-ťńe 'these, DEF', śe  'that', śe-ťńe 'those, DEF' can be used independently.

Name: Is the order of possessive suffix and case suffix across the paradigm the same?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The possessive suffixes usually follow case suffixes: keď-eze-nze (hand-ILL.PX.3SG>3SG) 'into his/her hand', except GEN (-nze/-nzo), which follows the stem, and DAT (-nst-eń) with the case suffix following the possessive suffix: ava-nzo/-nst-eń mother-PX.3SG>3SG 'his/her mother / to his/her mother'. GEN and DAT are mainly used with kinship terms.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: viŕ-ť forest-NOM.PL 'forests'; vir'-es' forest-DEF.NOM.SG 'the forest', vir-en't' forest-DEF.GEN.SG 'of the forest', vir'-en't'en' forest-DEF.DAT=ILL. SG 'to the forest', vir'-d'en't' forest-DEF.ABL.SG 'about the forest', vir'-t'n'e forest-DEF.NOM.PL 'the forests', śorma-ťńe-ďe letter-DEF.ABL.PL 'about the letters'; POSS.declension: possession and number marker follows the case marker: ked'-em hand-POSS.NOM.1SG 'my hand', ked'-sten' hand-POSS.ELA.1SG>3PL 'out of my hands'.
Comment: INDF declension: plural t/t' occurs only in NOM; DEF.declension: in Nom.SG - the DEF. marker  s', in GEN.SG - GEN.n' + t', in DAT.SG - n't'+ case marker, in the other forms - a case marker+ n't', the DEF.PL  case markers follow the marker t'n'e (PL t' + DEF. n'e);  POSS.declension: the number+possession marker follows the case marker marker.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: l'el'a 'uncle' is used for both.

Name: Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: There is only distinction for 'old', i.e. tašto 'old (inanimate), sire 'old (animate)', cf. od 'new, young'.

Name: Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: There is only distinction for 'cold': jakšamo 'cold' is used about (winter) weather, day (cf. also jakšamo-s' 'frost, cold weather), whereas kel'me 'cold' is used in a wide range of meanings, e.g. moda-s' kel'me 'the soil is cold', ked'-et' kel'me 'your hand is cold'.

Name: Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The  inherent length of vowels in a word, rather than stress affects the relationship between vowel lengths - stressed U may be shorter than unstressed a:  nUla 'a piece of cloth'; intrinsically, the high vowels, u, i are shorter than the low a; the length of the stressed i, u may be equal to (or even longer than) that of the unstressed a.

Name: Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: No genuine geminates; at morpheme boundary, false geminates may be formed: van-n-oms (see-FRQ-INF).

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Quantity has no phonological significance.

Name: Are there extralong syllables?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kudosonzo [ˈkudoˌsonzo] home-PX.3SG>3SG-INE
Comment: Mainly disyllabic trochaic feet are realized in speech: kUdo-sOnzo home-PX.3SG>3SG-INE.  Trisyllabic feet (e.g. kUdosost home-PX.3SG>3PL) are possible. Stress can move across word boundaries: ćOra-ťńE eźť tUje-vE kudO-v man-DEF.NOM.PL NEG-PST1.3SG leave.CNG home-INDF.LAT.SG 'The men did/could not leave.' Stress is not distinctly expressed.

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The variants of the emphatic particle (clitic) -jak/-kak/-gak 'even, too' (e.g. sOn-gAk 'he, too') tend to have primary or secondary stress.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: The first syllable tends to be stressed if the word is uttered as a dictionary item; in words with more than two syllables, stressed and unstressed syllables alternate: mOdamAŕ 'potato'.

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Initial and non-initial stress alternate (in the example, vowel of the stressed syllable is marked with capital letters): mon E-źiń mO-ľe /mOn e-źIń mo-ĺE 1SG.NOM NEG go.CNG 'I did not go'.

Name: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ťejťeŕ-ťńe girl-DEF.NOM.PL, piks-tne rope-DEF.NOM.PL
Comment: Front vowel harmony in conjunction with palatalized consonant, which causes suffix variation, e.g. -ťńe/-tne.

Name: Is there velar vowel harmony?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kunsoloms
Comment: Back vowel harmony, including a: kunsolo-ms 'to listen', lomań 'person' is canceled by palatalized C: muśke-ms ' to wash clothes'. Some suffixes (e.g. -ś DEF) do not obey vowel harmony: śokś-e-ś 'the autumn', soks-o-ś 'the ski'.

Name: Is there labial vowel harmony?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there rising diphthongs?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: There are no diphthongs.

Name: Are there lowering diphthongs?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: There are no diphthongs.

Name: Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: In South-Eastern dialects, reduced vowels occur in unstressed syllables (showing different patterns of non-contrustive distribution); in some words, a vowel having the quality of a reduced V may appear in a stressed syllable: pUromo-ms/pUrǝmǝ-ms/pƏrǝmǝ-ms 'get together'.

Name: Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: In South-Eastern dialects, e - ä: keď 'hand, arm' - käď 'leather, skin'; word-final e, i > ä: śimi > śimä 's/he drinks' .

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: kši [kʃi] 'bread'
Comment: CC(C) occur in (i) a group of old loans: kši 'bread', (ii) onomatopoeia: kravto-ms 'chase away', (iii) lexical or style variants: pŕa/piŕa 'head', and (iv) composite words: śńaro 'how many/much'.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: piškaďems [ˈpi.ʃka.dʲems]  'to address', por.ks-ams 'to break'
Comment: pi.škaď-ems (> pška.-ďems)

Name: Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: karkstomo [ˈkarks.to.mo] belt-ABE.SG 'without a belt'

Name: Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: karkstomo [ˈkarks.to.mo] belt-ABES.SG 'without a belt', kev-ksť-ńe-ms 'to inquire, ask', jarmak-ťńe money-DEF.NOM.PL
Comment: They occur mainly in suffixes (as the result of elision).

Name: Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: valks 'dictionary', kaŕ-ks-t 'ropes'
Comment: CC(C) occurring mainly in suffixes (as the result of vowel elision).

Name: Are there palatalized dentals?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: śiśem [ˈsʲi.sʲem] 'seven'
Comment: ť ď ś ź ć ń ŕ ľ, e.g. śiśem 'seven', ťoža 'thousand', ľem 'name', -ďeŕa (suffix, conditional), ńeje-ms 'to see', seŕ 'height'.

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Before front vowels, labials and velars may be palatalized.

Name: Is there palatal stop [c]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: In dialects, palatalized č: čama 'face', čumo 'guilt', čeŕ 'hair'.

Name: Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Dialect variation: kov/koŋ 'moon, month', positional nasalization n + k, g: kengeľ-ems 'to tell lies', ponkst 'trousers', kenkš 'a door'.

Name: Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: copaďems [ˈt͡so.pa.dʲems] 'grab', ćora 'man, boy'

Name: Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: či [t͡ʃi] 'day', pačk 'through'

Name: Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: ška [ʃka] 'time', peškśe 'full'

Name: Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: veďga [ˈvedʲ.ga] water-PROL

Name: Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: raužo 'black', raśke 'ethnos, people', ruma-ms 'become bleached', Rav 'Volga', ruz 'Russian'

Name: Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Example: xoľams [ˈxo.lʲams] 'to whip'

Name: Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: A positional variant: v > w/u, e.g. avoľ > awuĺ/auľ 'not'.

Name: Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
Comment: Only in loanwords, e.g. fizika 'physics', Feďa/Xveďa (name).

Name: Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk

Name: Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
Source: Niina Aasmäe, Mariann Bernhardt, Denys Teptiuk
